results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 19. Asia
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest, Channel Four, Bricomin Films and John Selwyn Gilbert
results.brief_description:
Episode number 19 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
Asian history, over the period 1600 - 1800, is examined in this episode, focusing on the countries of Japan, China and India. European influence was always at Asia’s door, but the final dominance from Europe did not come until 1800 - 1950. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 18. The West and Wider World
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and John Selwyn Gilbert
results.brief_description:
Episode number 18 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines the period of European history covering 1500 - 1800. At this time, Europe entered the race to travel the seas for commodities such as spices and the conquering of far-off lands. Portugal entered this race, also trading in another commodity - slavery.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 18. The West and Wider World
results.creator_credit_for_label: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and John Selwyn Gilbert

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 17. Europe: State and Power
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and John Selwyn Gilbert
results.brief_description:
Episode number 17 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines the period of European history covering 1453 - 1700. At this time, Europe was no longer threatened by invading Turkey, and in the 16th and 17th century, North Western Europe became the dominant region. The 16th century brought change, evolution and expansion to agriculture, trade, painting, military, religion and science. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 17. Europe: State and Power

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 16. The Americas before the Europeans
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode number 16 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
AD 300 - 1500. Unlike other places, ancient America was illiterate, so all that was left of these civilisations were the majestic ruins of their cities and places of worship. By the 9th century this society had collapsed and everything had been abandoned - perhaps it was an epidemic or an invasion. By between the 7th and 10th centuries Barbarian tribes invaded Mexico. Today there are still Indians - the people still eat and dress like their ancestors did, but the political destiny of Latin America lay in the hands of the Europeans. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 15. Africa before the Europeans
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four, Nicholas Barton and David Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode number 15 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers the history of Africa over the period 100-1500AD. Before the 15th Century, Africa was a rich continent of civilisations and empires, and the Nile was the lifeblood of the people. By AD 1000, Islam had the whole of North Africa in its grasp. To the Europeans, Africa was known as “the Dark Continent”, and by the 18th century they were transporting people from Africa for the slave trade. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 15. Africa before the Europeans

description_for_label:
Episode number 15 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers the history of Africa over the period 100-1500AD. Before the 15th Century, Africa was a rich continent of civilisations and empires, and the Nile was the lifeblood of the people. By AD 1000, Islam had the whole of North Africa in its grasp. To the Europeans, Africa was known as “the Dark Continent”, and by the 18th century they were transporting people from Africa for the slave trade. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 14. The Ottoman Empire
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode number 14 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines the expansion of the Turkish Empire under the rule of the Ottomans, and later the decline of the Empire over the period 1280 - 1683.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 13. China and Japan
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode number 13 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers Chinese and Japanese history over the period 1279 - 1644. It looks at Chinese civilisation under the Mongols from 1234 - 1367, followed by the rise and fall of the Ming Dynasty over the period 1368 - 1644. Aspects of Feudal Japanese civilisation are examined; and this episode also looks at the arrival of the first European travellers, in the 16th Century, bringing Christianity and firearms with them. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 13. China and Japan
results.creator_credit_for_label: Network Television, Goldcrest, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 12. China in Transition
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode number 12 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines Chinese history over the period 581 - 1279. This period included a time of rich development for Chinese civilisation, and this program examines the influence of Chinese Buddhism on the Sui and Tang people. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.creator_credit_for_label: Network Television, Goldcrest, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 11. The Expansion of Europe
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode number 11 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode covers a period of history from 1250-1500 that resulted in dramatic changes in Europe. Major conflicts continued as different countries struggled for power, and, although it was a time of great exploration and development, it was also a time of great disaster, with overpopulation, famine and plague sweeping across the continent. Based on The Times atlas of world history.

results.title: The World: A Television History. Ep. 10. The Mongol Onslaught
results.creator_credit: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “The World: A Television History”.
This episode examines the reign of terror by Genghis Khan, and the continuation of this reign over the period 850 - 1500. The history of his rule is traced, beginning with Peking, which was the first of many cities to feel the fury of the Khan’s obsession to conquer all of China. Based on The Times atlas of world history.
results.title_for_label: The World: A Television History. Ep. 10. The Mongol Onslaught
results.creator_credit_for_label: Network Television, Goldcrest TV, Bricomin Films, Channel Four and David Wright
